Q1: Do students that are in a relationship drink more at the weekend?

  • We will use a two sampled paired t-test. We are comparing ‘relationship’ which is a nominal categorical variable with level of alcohol consumption, an ordinal categorical variable. We state the null hypothesis below:
  • h0: mu_inRel <= mu_sgl
  • h1: mu_inRel > mu_sgl
  • a = 0.05 (95% confidence)

Descriptive statistics of variables

#Get descriptive statistics by group to show a matrix of alcohol consumption by those in a relationship and those that are not. Mean of those in a relationship that drink is a little larger than those that are not. Standard deviations are less than 2 so we can use a student t-test. Both are positively skewed with a platykurtic distribution(Moderately Spread Out).
psych::describeBy(smath$Walc.m, smath$romantic.m, mat=TRUE)

Levene’s test for homogeneity of variance

#We conduct Levene's test for homogeneity of variance. The null hypothesis is that variances in relationship and weekend alcohol consumption are equal so to assume homogeneity we would expect probability to not be statistically significant.
car::leveneTest(smath$Walc.m ~ smath$romantic.m, center=mean)
## Warning in leveneTest.default(y = y, group = group, ...): group coerced to
## factor.
#our probability Pr(>F) is greater than 0.05 so it is not statistically significant so we can assume homogeneity.

Student T-Test

stats::t.test(Walc.m~romantic.m,var.equal=TRUE,data=smath)
## 
##  Two Sample t-test
## 
## data:  Walc.m by romantic.m
## t = -0.35172, df = 380, p-value = 0.7252
## alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group no and group yes is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  -0.3274186  0.2280551
## sample estimates:
##  mean in group no mean in group yes 
##          2.264368          2.314050
  • No statistically significant difference was found so we do not reject the null hypothesis. We cannot say with a 95% confidence level that math students in a relationship drink more at the weekend than those that do not.

What is the difference between maths students who perform bad on final grades vs those who perform well

We will use a two sampled paired t-test. We are comparing two groups of students (bad + good) from the same school. Weekend Alcohol standard dev is 1.06 and math grade 3 is 4.66 mG3. There is a difference between these two by 0.22 which means we must use Welch’s test (s1/s2<0.5) h0: good performing students and bad performing students drink the same amount of alcohol h1: bad performing students drink more alcohol

h0: mu1 = mu2 h1: mu2>mu1

#mothers education on grades? #alcohol on grades? # h1: students who spend more time studying get better grades #relationship status on grades?
